Award.AwardTitle: Facilities to enhance collaborative research at UGA Costa Rica
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Georgia Research Foundation is awarded a grant to renovate a wet laboratory, add a back-up power generator, and improve network infrastructure at their UGA Costa Rica field station in San Luis, Costa Rica. UGA Costa Rica is rapidly becoming a premier study-abroad location, hosting over 1600 students, faculty, and other leaders from more than 57 educational institutions and NGOs in 2011. These enhanced facilities will improve continuity of operations, connectivity, and scientific research collaboration capabilities at the station. Located at the Monteverde Cloud Forest Reserve the station has built a unique relationship with the nearby farming community of San Luis enabling unprecedented integration of training, outreach, service learning, and social and ecological research opportunities. Research opportunities range from focal studies in traditional disciplines to broad socio- ecological studies addressing conservation challenges throughout the Bellbird Biological Corridor (BBC), connecting the cloud forest to the Pacific coast. BBC research needs include addressing important problems facing ecosystems and human communities as a result of historic deforestation and current land use conflicts. UGA offers rich study abroad experiences at the field station and the renovation of the wet laboratory will increase utility and productivity in conducting scientific research. The back-up generator will eliminate frequent power interruptions affecting communications, sample processing and storage, and computational work. Finally, a new server and network switch will enhance network access and data sharing applications, allowing UGA Costa Rica to host a much needed web mapping service to share data with researchers and stakeholders.

Through the tight integration of research, education and community service at UGA Costa Rica, enhanced facilities will not only improve research capacity but will also enhance the training of more than a thousand students each year and improve environmental literacy in the surrounding communities. Providing a foundation for reliable connectivity and effective data-sharing will enhance collaborations between disciplines and institutions, among U.S. and Costa Rican academies, industry and government, and also with other international partners through individual research projects. As there is currently no other reliable hub for geo-spatial information-sharing in the Bellbird Biological Corridor, that aspect alone will serve many partners and researchers alike. This project directly addresses the broader impacts of our science by reaching out to current and future scientists in the U.S. and in Costa Rica, as well as addressing local and regional needs for information to inform conservation decision- making.

For more information about UGA Costa Rica please visit: http://www.externalaffairs.uga.edu/costa_rica/index.php/front_desk/overview

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Georgia’s Costa Rica field station (UGA Costa Rica) is rapidly becoming a premier education abroad location, where its relationship to the farming community of San Luis near the Monteverde Cloud Forest enables an unprecedented integration of training, outreach, service-learning and research on important social and environmental problems. Research opportunities span the conservation challenges from the cloud forest to the mangrove communities in the Gulf of Nicoya. UGA has invested heavily in opportunities for education abroad experiences, but has recently recognized the need for a coordinated vision to bring research into balance with instruction. Thus, in 2010 the university leadership stated that the mission of UGA Costa Rica would be “to advance our understanding - through instruction, research and outreach - of the interconnected nature of human and environmental systems, particularly the concepts of socio-cultural, ecological, and economic sustainability." Realizing this vision depends on the enhancement of research infrastructure. This project provided three primary improvements in support of this mission: 1) A laboratory renovation provided a modern working environment that meets safety requirements and storage needs; 2) A 50,000 kWh back-up generator will prevent loss of important research resources during power outages; and 3) Computational infrastructure enhancements that improve scientific computing power, and allow the campus to share important data about the region with other researchers and the public.

Although it has only been a short time since the improvements, outcomes of this work have already been invaluable. First, several faculty, graduate students, and interns have commented that their work was supported by the new generator coming on during regular power outages. Under previous conditions, unsaved work was frequently lost, and under the longer outages, valuable samples in frozen storage have been lost. As a direct result of the enhanced lab facilities, UGA CR is inheriting a massive insect collection from Inbioparque, which will result in the largest collection of moths and butterflies (Lepidoptera) in Costa Rica, and perhaps one of the largest in the world. In addition, a variety of undergraduate programs and high school groups that visit UGA CR have used the lab as an invaluable instructional resource. This lab will be a major selling point in expanding the types of research and outreach that can be conducted on-site. Finally, the computing infrastructure has allowed us to meet current and future demands for internet connectivity, data storage, and high end computing that is required to analyze and share information. In addition, we have been able to build and demonstrate an internet map service for sharing maps and data with the research community and with the public, which will soon go live.

Collectively, these important improvements to the UGA Costa Rica campus infrastructure have enhanced research capacity through improved safety, security, and connectivity. Because UGA Costa Rica has such a strong local network of partners, and plays a large role in regional conservation, ongoing research and outreach efforts stand to improve the sustainability of water resources, species habitat, and people’s lives throughout the region.
